newsitem.title: ISRAEL: SOCCER-WOSZ SCORES ON GERMANY DEBUT.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-WOSZ SCORES ON GERMANY DEBUT.

text.p: Dariusz Wosz marked his debut for European champions Germany with a late winner in the friendly against Israel on Wednesday.
Wosz, who won seven pre-1990 caps for East Germany, struck the only goal of the match in the 85th minute.
He pounced after central defender Gadi Brumer failed to clear a high ball into the penalty area.
In the first match between unified Germany and Israel, the host side, missing several key players, more than held their own in the first half.
But the Germans held the upper hand for much of the second half and eventually broke Israel's stout resistance when Bochum's Wosz was quick to take advantage of Brumer's error.
Wosz's strike was rough justice on Israel goalkeeper Rafi Cohen who made a string of fine saves in the second half.
Israel, without the potent finishing power of the injured Ronnen Harazi and lacking the creative midfield skills of Eyal Berkovic and Haim Revivo, lacked the spark which might have made a difference.
"There was a distinct difference between our play in the first and second halves," said relieved Germany coach Berti Vogts.
"Despite the Israelis' excellent play in the first half we played well later on and deserved this result, no doubt about it.
"But perhaps if the match had ended in a 1-1 draw it would have given me a better excuse to push the players harder for our forthcoming World Cup qualifiers."
Israel coach Shlomo Scharf was full of praise for his team. "I am not disappointed with the result," he said. "To have lost to Germany 1-0 is no disgrace, particularly after the way we played.
"Even without several of our best players we managed to play against them on an even footing."
